Il Lombardia 2023: Everything you need to know

The 2023 edition of Il Lombardia will take place on Saturday 7th October over a hilly 238km route from Como to Bergamo in Italy. The last of the five Monuments on the WorldTour calendar, ‘The Race of the Falling Leaves’ is one of the hardest one-day races of the season and for most it’s the final major appointment on the road calendar.

The course is similar to the 2021 edition won by Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates), again scaling the Madonna del Ghisallo, Roncola, Berbenno and Zambla Alta before the Passo di Ganda on the way to Bergamo. The famed Muro di Sormano misses out again in 2023.

Historically, Il Lombardia has favoured punchy climbers, with recent winners including Pogačar in 2021 and 2022, Bauke Mollema (Trek-Segafredo) in 2019 and Thibaut Pinot (Groupama-FDJ) in 2018. Il Lombardia will mark Pinot’s final race as a professional cyclist.

A stacked start list will descend on Como this year, including defending champion Pogačar alongside Primož Roglič (Jumbo-Visma) and Remco Evenepoel (Soudal-QuickStep). Below, Cyclist has compiled a guide of all you need to know heading into the 117th edition of Il Lombardia.

Il Lombardia 2023: Key information

  • Date: Saturday 7th October
  • Start: Como
  • Finish: Bergamo
  • Distance: 238km
  • 2022 winner: Tadej Pogačar
  • Most wins: Fausto Coppi (five)

Il Lombardia 2023: The route

When the race first appeared in 1905, it took the form of a loop to and from Milan. From the 1960s until the early 2000s, the race would then start or finish in Milan with the opposing venue being another location within the Lombardia region. Between 2004 and 2006, the race even started in the Swiss town of Mendrisio.

Since 2014, however, the race has settled on switching start and finish locations between the beautiful cities of Bergamo and Como. In 2023, the peloton depart from Como and head towards the first climb of the Madonna del Ghisallo (8.km, 4%) from the Asso side, which stands 30km into the day. At its summit is the Church of Madonna del Ghisallo (the patron saint of cycling), which houses a shrine dedicated to cycling, a small museum of artefacts and an eternal flame burning for all cyclists who have died.

From there, a series of attritional climbs stand in their way, starting with the Roncola Alta (9.4km, 6.6%) and Berbenno (6.8km, 4.6%) before the one-two punch of the Passo Della Crocetta (11km, 6.2%) and Zambla Alta (9.5km, 3.5%), the Passo di Ganda (9.2km, 7.3%) and the short, cobbled final act of the Colle Aperto (1.1km, 7.9%).

After paying homage to the cycling gods, the steep slopes of Roncola will have riders praying for it to get easier.

Prayers are answered with the steady Berbenno ascent.

But the following pair is pretty much 24km of climbing.

Unless Evenepoel goes from 60km out, a big selection is likely to be made on the Passo Di Ganda.

In the final kilometres, the remaining riders will fight over 200m of cobblestones on the Colle Aperto to get the total elevation to around 4,400m before descending towards the finish line in Bergamo. A gap over the top could be decisive, or it could be a sprint to the line.

Il Lombardia 2023: Live TV guide and how to watch

GCN+ will be showing the 2023 Il Lombardia live to subscribers from 09:00 BST – 16:00 BST. Both short and extended highlights will be available after the race. GCN+ costs £6.99 paid monthly, or £39.99 per year and Discovery+ costs £6.99 per month or £59.99 per year for sports and entertainment (for fans of shows like Wheeler Dealers and Naked and Afraid).

The 2023 Il Lombardia will also be shown on TV, with coverage on Eurosport 1 beginning at 10:10 BST.

Il Lombardia 2023: Previous winners

2021 – Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates)
2020 – Jakob Fuglsang (Astana-Premier Tech)
2019 – Bauke Mollema (Trek-Segafredo)
2018 – Thibaut Pinot (Groupama-FDJ)
2017 – Vincenzo Nibali (Bahrain-Merida)
2016 – Esteban Chaves (Orica-BikeExchange)
2015 – Vincenzo Nibali (Astana)
2014 – Dan Martin (Garmin-Sharp)
2013 – Joaquim Rodriquez (Team Katusha)
2012 – Joaquim Rodriquez (Team Katusha)
2011 – Oliver Zaugg (Leopard-Trek)
2010 – Philippe Gilbert (Omega Pharma-Lotto)

Most wins – 5: Fausto Coppi (ITA), 1946, 1947, 1948, 1949, 1954.
First winner – 1905: Giovanni Gerbi (ITA).
